  How the Tweel Airless Tire Works
  For more than 100 years, vehicles have been rolling along on cushions of air encased in rubber, but a new design by Michelin could change things. The Tweel Airless Tire looks sort of like a very large, futuristic bicycle wheel, but it absorbs impacts without using pressurized air. Learn how the 
Tweel Airless Tire works and where you might see it used in the future.
 Also at HowStuffWorks
 
How Fuel Injection Systems Work - The 1990 Subaru Justy was the last car model in the United States to have a carburetor. Now, all new cars have fuel injection systems. Learn how the fuel gets into the cylinder of the engine and how performance chips can give your engine more power. 
 
How Seatbelts Work - "Buckle up" and "Click it or ticket" are popular slogans aimed at getting people to wear their seatbelts. But what does a seatbelt actually do? How can a piece of fabric end up being the difference between life and death? Learn how seatbelts react in a crash. 
 
2009 Chevrolet Camaro Review and Prices - Peek into the future -- and remember the past -- with the 2009 Chevrolet Camaro. Its styling was inspired by the 1969 Camaro, a one-year body style valued today by collectors. Read about the 2009 Camaro's features and see pictures of its interior and exterior.  
   
This Week's Video 
How Drawbridges Work - If you've ever been stuck in traffic while a drawbridge holds up a long line of cars to let a single boat pass through, you might not appreciate the technology at work, but drawbridges are pretty cool inventions nevertheless. Learn more in this HowStuffWorks
